intro: Stenogyne scrophularioides var. biflora, commonly known as the Hawaiian ironwood, is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a shrub or small tree characterized by its dark, fissured bark and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, fragrant flowers that are typically white or pale blue, arranged in clusters. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in mesic to wet forest habitats. Due to its limited distribution and ecological importance, it is considered a vulnerable species.
